thread.title_full: ResponsibleOhio has spent $15.4 million on campaign to legalize pot | The Columbus Dispatch

author: The Columbus Dispatch
title: ResponsibleOhio has spent $15.4 million on campaign to legalize pot
text:
The group backing a marijuana ballot issue has spent $15.4 million so far on its campaign, $12 million in the past three months. 

ResponsibleOhio has been waging an all-out campaign, much of it in 30-second television commercials, for State Issue 3, the marijuana legalization constitutional amendment Ohioans will decide in the Nov. 3 election. 

A campaign finance report filed today with Secretary of State Jon Husted’s office showed ResponsibleOhio received more than $11.9 million through the Oct. 14 cutoff in contributions and spent nearly the same amount. The contributors were largely investments groups which would own and operate the 10 commercial marijuana growing sites around the state which would be permitted if the issue passes. 

The vast majority of donations came from nine investment groups, accounting for $11,966,000 in 78 separate donations. DGF LLC, owned by Frank “Bo” Wood, an investor in the Clermont County farm and head of Secret Communications, a Cincinnati investment firm, was the largest single donor at $2.35 million, according to the campaign finance report. 

ResponsibleOhio also had 237 individual contributors who gave a total of $7,695 in amounts ranging from $2 to $200. 

ResponsibleOhio previously filed reports showing it raised nearly $3.5 million and spent $3.4 million, much of it on the signature-collection effort to get the issue on the ballot. Ian James, ResponsibleOhio’s executive director, is the co-owner The Strategy Network, the company in charge of gathering signatures of registered voters. 

The amendment would legalize use of recreational marijuana by Ohioans 21 and older and medical marijuana by anyone with a medical condition certified by a physician. There would be up to 1,159 marijuana shops allowed around the state, plus medical marijuana dispensaries. 

Marijuana sales would be taxed at the wholesale and retail level, with revenue channeled mostly to cities, counties and townships. 

Ohioans Against Marijuana Monopolies, the broad coalition opposing Issue 3, has not yet filed a campaign report. 

Dispatch reporter Randy Ludlow contributed to this report.
